Dear Mr. Weaver:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
04/21/22. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
the Modified Implementation, Sustainability, and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a
written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing
rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violation, identify why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of human
services, the equivalent state or Canadian provincial agency, or
equivalent agency in the country where the person usually
resides, that the person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect. The documentation
shall be completed not more than 30 days prior to the start of
employment and every 12 months thereafter.
One of 14 new employee files reviewed was found to be missing a MDHHS
abuse/neglect clearance. The employee is a student at a local college and has an
out of state permanent address. The other state’s abuse/neglect clearance was
completed but not the Michigan clearance. Given the time the individual resides in
Michigan during school, the clearance is required. The facility has submitted for the
clearance at this time. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 03/15/21, and CAP,
03/17/21. The facility must report why the previous CAP failed and how they
will ensure compliance.
R 400.4152 Initial documentation.
At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the
resident's case record:
(b) A photograph taken within the previous 12 months.
(i) Documentation that the grievance policy was provided as
required in R 400.4132.
(b) One of six files reviewed did not contain a current photo of the youth.
(i) One of six files reviewed did not contain documentation that the grievance policy
was provided.
1

R 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan.
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and date an
initial treatment plan for each resident within 30 calendar days
of admission.
(3) The initial treatment plan shall include all of the following:
(c) Treatment goals to remedy the problems of the resident
and family, and time frames for achieving the goals.
(h) For youth who are permanent court wards or MCI wards,
there must be documented co-ordination with the agency
assigned to complete adoption or permanency planning for the
youth.
(1) One of three applicable files reviewed was found to have the initial service plan
submitted one day late.
(3)(c) Two of two applicable files had initial treatment plans with no timeframes for
the family goals.
(3) (h) One applicable file reviewed did not document contact with the adoption
worker.
R 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan.
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and date an
updated treatment plan for each resident at least once every 90-
calendar days following the initial treatment plan.
(1) One of three applicable files reviewed was found to have the updated service
plan submitted two days late.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there

3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract/Policy violation. Please
note that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is not contracted with DHHS; therefore, no
contract or policy requirements apply.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 113
I recommended the facility put the employee’s names on their reference check forms.
It was advised that the facility run annual criminal history clearances.
R 128
The facility was advised to ensure that all required training topics outlined in the rule
are addressed clearly for each employee. I urged the facility Chief Administrator to
ensure more timely initial restraint training for new employees. Employees without the
training are not able to use physical restraint or escort youth.
R 140
The facility was advised to ensure that they are clearly documenting compliance with
their written vehicle maintenance policy. Review and update your policy if needed.
R 146
The facility was advised to be clearer with documentation of parental refusal for
immunizations. The parent refusal should document the date the refusal occurred,
which parent refused (or both), and be signed by the parents. If the parents will not
sign, the person taking the information should document their name and attempt to
get the parental consent and signatures of refusal.
R 153
The facility was advised to be more specific in identifying the services to be provided.
R 155(2) and R 156(2)
The facility was advised to clearly identify who, out of the required individuals in the
rule, provided input in the report (sources of information exchange) and not just the
document sources reviewed.
R 155
The facility was advised to elaborate on their plan for visitation and not just state
visiting hours. The plan should note how visits start and how that time is expanded
from onsite visits that transition to home visits.
R 159
Upon review of the facility's updated policy on restraint, it was noted that the policy
needs to be updated and not just a restatement of the rule requirements.
R 166
The facility was reminded to use the youth’s next permanent location/address and not
the address of the person the youth was released to, such as the probation officer’s
address.
3

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Consultation was provided related to criminal clearances.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care or substantiated
corporal punishment during this licensing period.
The facility has submitted no acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. There have been three special
investigations during this period, but no violations were established in any of them.
One special investigation, 2022C0446023, was opened during this inspection so the
results will be assessed during the next period. The facility has low restraint and
seclusion numbers. Youth report feeling supported, respected, and that they are
benefiting from the program. The Chief Administrator Annual Assessment addressed
the prior violations and an incident that occurred during this period. Overall, it appears
that the facility makes ongoing efforts to comply with licensing rules.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on
their regular license.
